article.description: Donatas Zavackas scored 16 points to lead No. 3 Pittsburgh to an 80-61 victory over West Virginia on Tuesday night, giving the Panthers their best start in 73 years.
article.headline: Pitt gets hot to cool off Mountaineers in Morgantown
article.linkText: No. 3 Pitt buries West Virginia with 3-pointers
article.story: MORGANTOWN, W.Va. (AP) -- Pittsburgh and West Virginia are practically neighbors and it seemed like the visiting Panthers were playing at home. With a strong fan following making the trip 70 miles to the south, No. 3 Pittsburgh got balanced scoring and shot 63 percent from the field in an 80-61 victory Tuesday night. The Panthers (13-1, 3-0 Big East) have consecutive wins at West Virginia for the first time since 1934 and 1935. Pittsburgh coach Ben Howland said Morgantown is hardly a comfort zone, especially after having just one day to practice following a win at Rutgers on Sunday. "This is a tough place to play,'' Howland said. "I was very concerned about this game. To win back-to-back seasons here is really exciting.'' Donatas Zavackas led Pittsburgh with 16 points, while Julius Page, Ontario Lett and Jaron Brown each had 14. The crowd of 13,891 did nothing to faze the Panthers as they went 10-of-18 from 3-point range and led by double digits throughout the second half. "After coming from Rutgers, you don't play in tougher places,'' Page said. "Once we were out there, we didn't hear anything and just handled business.'' West Virginia (9-5, 1-2) lost for the first time at home this season and was held to its third-lowest point total of the season. "This wasn't about West Virginia. This was about how good Pitt is right now,'' first-year Mountaineers coach John Beilein. "They show a lot of qualities that I've seen in some of the teams that went a long way in March.'' West Virginia's two previous conference games were against inside-oriented offenses. Pittsburgh posed a different threat with five players averaging in double figures. Pittsburgh's Brandin Knight, last year's Big East player of the year, was held to six points on 2-of-8 shooting, but it didn't matter. Pittsburgh had too many weapons against a Mountaineers team that starts three freshmen and two sophomores. "From top to bottom, Pitt is solid. No weak links,'' West Virginia center Kevin Pittsnogle said. "We'll just learn from being on the same court as them. We just didn't play up to our potential.'' West Virginia used up most of the shot clock in search of an open look, often with nothing to show for it. Pittsburgh native Drew Schifino led the Mountaineers with 18 points and Pittsnogle had 14. Pittsburgh hit its first five shots, but the lead changed hands eight times early in the first half. Knight hit a 3-pointer -- his first basket -- to start a 10-0 run for a 31-22 lead with 4:10 left in the half. The Panthers built on a 12-point halftime lead with an array of 3-pointers and inside baskets. Knight's long basket made it 48-30 3:30 into the second half, and Zavackas' 3-pointer gave the Panthers their largest lead, 72-51, with 4:05 remaining. Zavackas was 4-of-4 from 3-point range. "Our confidence and experience is what helps us most in conference games,'' Zavackas said. "From playing together for so long, to making the (NCAA) Sweet 16 last year, our experience helps us more than anything.''
